title: I Love You, Now Die: Unravelling the untold story you thought you knew
text:
I Love You, Now Die is the story you thought you knew (Picture: Sky/HBO)

True Crime has become more than a morally debatable new phenomenon in entertainment – our perception of the truth is now blurred beyond recognition. For years murders were solved, cases were closed but now, and only now, we’ve realised the story we were told had more than one side.

Sally Challen was one a ‘scorned wife who killed her husband with a hammer’ because he didn’t want to be with her anymore. Now she’s the victim of coercive control.

Sky Crime launched this week and among the first of its major new investigations is HBO’s I Love You, Now Die, following the infamous 2014 suicide of 18-year-old Conrad Roy, who was encouraged to end his life by girlfriend Michelle Carter.

Carter was a public monster. ‘Drink bleach’ and ‘Hang yourself jump off a building stab yourself idk theres (Sic.) lots of ways,’ are just two of many messages from Carter found on Roy’s phone. How could she not be to blame for his death?

I Love You, Now Die confronts the hazy guilt. Where does the fault lie?

In episode one, Roy’s family recall his final days, his relationship with Carter and her involvement after he was found suffocated in the driver’s seat of his car. Initially, it appears there’s little to speculate – Carter lied about her knowledge of Roy’s plans, his whereabouts and set up a fundraiser in her hometown – not his – because on the surface she was enjoying the attention. ‘I’m like famous now haha,’ she wrote to one friend.

During the 2017 trial, the media painted a similar picture.

Episode two, however, reveals Carter and Roy’s relationship was more disturbing than we knew, and the toxic texts were mutual.

Throughout their 18-month relationship, Roy sent images of nooses and guns with captions such as ‘f**k you b***h.’ She urged him to seek help, pleaded with Roy to find another solution until she flipped and suddenly began to encourage him a few months before it was all over.

I Love You, Now Die examines Carter’s relatively unreported use of drugs prescribed by her doctors to combat mental health, and the dangerous game of online dating – painting a picture of a person who doesn’t really exist.

Consultant Forensic Psychologist Kerry Daynes spoke to press including Metro.co.uk at the launch of Sky Cime to explain the vitality of exploring these complex narratives, which have otherwise suffered from one-dimensional reporting.

‘I think that’s’ what our audience wants,’ said Daynes. ‘Gone are the days when true crime was the Pot Noodle of television, something you’d watch at 2am in the morning and it was bad guy doing something terrible to the ideal victim.

Michelle Carter was sentenced for the death of Conrad Roy (Picture: AP)

‘I think it perpetuates stereotypes which are harmful in the real world. We live in a world where juries are reluctant to convict ordinary-looking men of rape and don’t believe victims when they come forward. Victims of sexual assault don’t want to come forward in fear of not being believed.’

Arguably the true crime phenomenon was born in Serial, which was later followed by the documentary The Case of Adnan Syed. Syed has been incarcerated since February 2000 and is currently serving a life sentence for the murder of Hae Min Lee, his girlfriend.

Since then, the armchair detective in all of us is determined to join the case as if we have even the slightest clue of what we’re on about. But through similar true crime series, thousands of witnesses who have never spoken out before have come forward, while social media has meant new evidence is falling into the right hands like never before.

Advertisement

‘When we tell these stories which force us to think more seriously – real people involved,’ Daynes continued. ‘They’re thinking about the people involved in those offenses and asking what does that say about us in society and it’s what people want – more complex, challenging stories.’

I Love You, Now Die is certainly a complex, challenging story. And one you thought you knew if it wasn’t for the true crime documentary.

I Love You, Now Die premieres this Sunday on Sky Crime and will be available on NOW TV.
